title: China: Samsung pulls out (as Tesla pulls in)
text:
One in, one out ....

Samsung, the world's biggest smartphone maker, has ended mobile phone production in China, the firm confirmed on Wednesday (October 2).

The shutdown comes months after it cut production at one plant - it suspended another factory there last year.

Competition is to blame: mid-2013 saw the Korean firm enjoy a 15 per cent share of what is the world's biggest smartphone market.

That had shrunk to one per cent in the first quarter of this year as it lost ground to homegrown brands like Huawei and Xiaomi.

The headlines were a sharp contrast to Tesla.

Sources say the U.S. electric vehicle maker aims to start production at its China factory this month.

The $2 billion plant - Tesla's first car manufacturing site overseas - gained key government approvals last month.

It is, though, unclear - the sources say - whether a production target of at least one thousand Model 3s a week is achievable, amid uncertainties around orders, labour and suppliers.

For Samsung too, there is a contrast - between China - and its footprint in Vietnam.

With eight factories and an R&D centre, it's invested more than 17 billion dollars there ...

And accounts for around one fifth of Vietnam's total exports.
